title: WCAS AF_AM_ST 380-0-2 Topics in African-American Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar explores the relationship between race and the state, specifically focusing on the extraordinary but contradictory role of government laws, policies, and regulations in defining and manipulating racial classification schemas, creating and maintaining circumstances of racial oppression, and alleviating and redressing racial inequality through anti-discrimination protections. Topics include the political development of racial census classifications, the New Deal and the emergence of the welfare state, criminal justice and mass incarceration, neoliberalism and poverty governance, and affirmative action policies and jurisprudence. Ultimately, we will examine the ways that the state and its political institutions actively produce categories of race, class, and gender, transform their meanings, and redefine their relationships to democratic ideals and prevailing models of U.S. politics and citizenship.
